sentences: Sarah Caldwell (March 6, 1924 – March 23, 2006) was an American opera conductor, impresario, and stage director.
She was a child prodigy and gave public performances on the violin by the time she was ten years old.
Caldwell graduated from Hendrix College in 1944 and attended the University of Arkansas as well as the New England Conservatory of Music.
She won a scholarship as a viola player at the Berkshire Music Center in 1946.
In 1947, she staged Vaughan Williams's Riders to the Sea.
For 11 years she served as the chief assistant to Boris Goldovsky.
Caldwell moved to Boston, Massachusetts, in 1952 and became head of the Boston University opera workshop.
In 1957 she started the Boston Opera Group with $5,000.

I Capuleti e i Montecchi, Montezuma (U.S. premiere), Ruslan and Ludmila (U.S. premiere), Rigoletto (with Sills, Richard Fredricks, and Susanne Marsee), Stiffelio (U.S. stage premiere), La damnation de Faust, Tosca (with Magda Olivero), La vide breve, El retablo de maese Pedro, The Ice Break (U.S. premiere), Aïda (with Shirley Verrett in the title role), Die Soldaten (U.S. premiere), The Invisible City of Kitezh, Taverner (U.S. premiere), The Makropoulos Case (with Anja Silja, William Cochran, and Chester Ludgin), Médée (in French and Greek), Dead Souls (U.S. premiere), Der Rosenkavalier (with Dame Gwyneth Jones) and, finally, The Balcony (world premiere, 1990).

sentences: In the 1980s, Opera New England, a branch of Ms. Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston, was the touring ambassador of opera to the New England states.
section: == Career == | === Productions with Opera Company Boston and related companies ===

sentences: At the New York City Opera, Caldwell staged Der junge Lord and Ariadne auf Naxos (with Carol Neblett), both in 1973.
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: She became the second woman to conduct the New York Philharmonic in 1974 with an all-female programme of composers including Ruth Crawford Seeger, Lili Boulanger and Thea Musgrave.
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: On 13 January 1976, Caldwell became the first female conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, with La traviata (with Sills).
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: In 1976, she both conducted and directed Il barbiere di Siviglia (with Sills and Alan Titus), which was televised over PBS.
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: In 1978, she led L'elisir d'amore at the Metropolitan, with José Carreras and Judith Blegen.
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: In 1979 she conducted and directed a televised production of Falstaff (with Donald Gramm).
section: == Career == | === Productions in New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota ===

sentences: Caldwell also directed one non-musical production, the 1981 Lincoln Center staging of Shakespeare's Macbeth, presented on cable TV in 1982.

sentences: In 1975 Caldwell received a D.F.A. from Bates College.
In 1997 she received the National Medal of Arts.
Caldwell retired in 2004.
She died in 2006 from heart failure at Maine Medical Center in Portland, Maine.
